raw_text:
UK young top Euro earnings league
 
 British children enjoy the highest average annual income in Europe - more than double that of Spanish or Italian youngsters, a report suggests.
 
 Children in the UK between the ages of 10 and 17 had an annual income of £775, said market analyst Datamonitor. They use "pester power" to get their parents to stump up nearly a third of this income, the report said. As for how they spend their cash, the bulk goes on personal care, soft drinks and food, Datamonitor said.
 
 Datamonitor adds that British teenagers are keen on personal care because it helps them combine two seemingly contradictory emotional needs - the desire to fit in and the desire to express their individuality.
 
 British teenage girls, compared to their counterparts in seven European countries, are the most keen to use make-up products. Nearly three out of four girls said they used make-up. According to the Datamonitor report the trend marked British teenagers out as "particularly important to cosmetics manufacturers as they are likely to experiment more with brands and products and form long-term beauty routines". And the good times are likely to keep rolling for British children, as the report predicts that they will still be topping the earnings table in 2008.
llama3.2:1b: UK children between 10-17 years old have an average annual income of £775, with nearly a third coming from their parents through "peser power". They spend most of this money on personal care, soft drinks and food, according to Datamonitor's market analysis. British teenagers are particularly interested in cosmetics products due to the desire for both social acceptance (fitting in) and self-expression (individuality).
llama3.2:3b: British children between 10-17 years old had an average annual income of £775, more than double that of Spanish or Italian youngsters. They use "pester power" to get parents to pay nearly a third of this income, with most spending on personal care, soft drinks, and food.
gemma2:2b: British children have the highest average annual income in Europe, exceeding double that of children in Spain or Italy.  They use a significant portion of this income on personal care products and related expenses. British teenagers are particularly enthusiastic about make-up and other beauty products, making them important to the cosmetics industry. The report predicts continued high earnings for UK children in 2008.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
UK teenagers make up a large portion of annual income, exceeding double that of their Spanish or Italian counterparts. They use "pester power" to get their parents to pay for nearly a third of their expenses. Personal care items like makeup are most popular among British teenage girls, who spend about three out of four days on personal grooming and dressing themselves as they try new brands and products.

Datamonitor predicts that UK children will still be in the top 10% of earners by 2008, compared to their counterparts in seven European countries.
qwen2.5:1.5b: The UK has the highest average annual income among European countries at £775 per child aged between 10 and 17, with nearly a third of this earned through "pester power". Approximately three-quarters of their income is spent on personal care items like makeup. The trend towards using cosmetics is seen as crucial for young British girls' future beauty routines and indicates the UK may remain at the top of earnings league in Europe until 2008.
qwen2.5:3b: UK young people enjoy the highest average annual income in Europe—over £775 per child aged 10-17, with parents contributing nearly a third of this. Children use much of their money on personal care, soft drinks, and food. UK teenagers leverage 'pester power' to influence spending decisions. They spend more than other European teens on cosmetics, especially make-up products, with almost three-quarters using them. The report predicts this trend will continue in 2008.

They use "pester power" to get their parents to stump up nearly a third of their income, compared to their Spaniards. As for how they spend their cash, most of their daily spending is personal care and food, with Datamonitor saying it helps in building their emotional needs - wanting to fit in and expressing their individuality. British teens are keen on using make-up products and the trend seems predicted by the report indicates that they will continue topping the earnings table in 2008.
smollm:1.7b: The UK's young people enjoy the highest average annual income in Europe, with more than double that of Spanish or Italian youngsters. They use "pester power" to get their parents to stump up nearly a third of this income, while also spending it on personal care, soft drinks and food. British teenagers are keen on personal care because it helps them combine two seemingly contradictory emotional needs - the desire to fit in and the desire to express their individuality.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Okay, I need to summarize this text about the UK young earning league. Let me read through it carefully.

The first sentence says that British children enjoy the highest average annual income in Europe—more than double Spanish or Italian kids. So I should include that part.

Next, the report mentions that the income is £775 for 10-17-year-olds, and they use "pester power" to get their parents to pay a third of their income. That's important because it explains how they make money.

The main point about spending on personal care, soft drinks, and food—those are the major expenses. So I'll mention that these activities help teenagers combine fitting in with wanting their individuality.

Then, the report talks about British teenage girls using makeup more often than their European counterparts. This is significant because it shows a trend they might experiment more with brands and products.

Lastly, the report notes that this spending is leading to better beauty routines and they'll be top earners in 2008. I should highlight how this trend continues into the future for British kids.

I need to make sure all these points are covered concisely without adding anything extra. Keep it straightforward as per the instructions.
</think>

The report highlights that British children earn more than double Spanish or Italian teenagers, with an annual income of £775 between 10-17 years old. They primarily spend on personal care, soft drinks, and food. Teenagers especially value personal care to combine fitting in with expressing their individuality. While British teenage girls use makeup more often, showing a trend towards experimenting with brands and products. This spending pattern is likely to continue, making them top earners by 2008.
tinyllama:1.1b: British children rank first among European countries with the highest average annual income in a study, according to a report by market analysis firm Datamonitor. The study found that British youngsters between the ages of 10 and 17 use "peser power" to get their parents to spend nearly a third of this income on personal care, soft drinks, and food. They are also keen on using cosmetics and are expected to form long-term beauty routines in 2008. Datamonitor notes that British teenagers are particularly interested in make-up, with almost three out of four girls using them.
tinydolphin:1.1b: The UK is reportedly the top European country with the highest average annual income for young people aged between 10 and 17. This high income level comes from children putting more effort into their personal care routines, spending nearly a third of their earnings on these items, according to a report by Datamonitor. The study found that British teenagers are particularly fond of make-up products, with almost three out of four girls admitting they use them regularly. This preference for cosmetics is attributed to the cultural importance placed upon self-expression among young Britons, who often feel the need to emulate the appearances of their peers in order to fit in and stand out from the crowd. The increasing popularity of make-up products indicates that British teenagers are developing a strong sense of identity within the bounds of their own style and culture.
phi:2.7b: According to a Datamonitor report, British teenagers have the highest average annual income in Europe, with an income of £775 between the ages of 10 and 17. They use "pester power" to convince their parents to contribute almost one-third of this money, which goes mainly towards personal care, soft drinks, and food. The report also notes that British teenage girls are particularly interested in using make-up products, making them important for cosmetics manufacturers.

However, this income is largely spent on personal care products, soft drinks, and food. British teenage girls are more likely to use makeup than their counterparts in other European countries. Despite a predicted decrease in earnings over the next few years, British children will still be among the highest-earning young people globally due to their financial prowess.
hermes3:3b: UK children have highest European youth income ($775 annually), over double Spanish/Italian counterparts.

Datamonitor attributes this behavior to teenagers combining their desires for fitting in and expressing individuality. British teenage girls are most likely to use make-up products, making them important to cosmetics manufacturers. Nearly a third of this income comes from parental contributions through "pester power." They primarily spend their money on personal care, soft drinks, and food. stablelm2:1.6b: British children have the highest average annual income in Europe at £10,000 per year, which is double compared to Spanish and Italian youngsters. UK children aged between 9-13 years old have an annual income of £5,0
granite3.1-dense:2b: British children aged 10-17 hold the highest average annual income among European youth, at £775, according to Datamonitor. Parents contribute nearly a third of this income, driven by "pester power." The majority of this income is spent on personal care, soft drinks, and food. British teenage girls are most likely to use makeup (nearly three-fourths), making them a significant market for cosmetics manufacturers. Datamonitor forecasts that the UK will maintain its top earning status in 2008.
reference: Children in the UK between the ages of 10 and 17 had an annual income of £775, said market analyst Datamonitor.They use "pester power" to get their parents to stump up nearly a third of this income, the report said.According to the Datamonitor report the trend marked British teenagers out as "particularly important to cosmetics manufacturers as they are likely to experiment more with brands and products and form long-term beauty routines".British children enjoy the highest average annual income in Europe - more than double that of Spanish or Italian youngsters, a report suggests.
